org_midgardproject_projectsite_document.title: Datagard
org_midgardproject_projectsite_document.content: <div><p>Datagard is the command-line tool for managing Midgard installations. After you have installed the Midgard1 packages on your system you can use it for setting up the Midgard environment.</p></div><div><p>Basic and easiest setup can be done by just running <i>datagard</i> command. Datagard will ask you questions, and guide you step by step through setup process.</p><p>Datagard will do the following operations for you:</p><ul><li>Set up a Midgard1 MySQL database</li><li>Create a new Apache virtual host to be used with Midgard</li><li>Install and set up a MidCOM environment</li></ul><h3>Command line options</h3></div><div><p><i>-t &lt;type of the setup&gt;</i></p><p>Type of the setup:</p><ul><li><i>quick</i>, datagard tries to determine sensible defaults for all configurations (this is usually a good choice for upgrades as then datagard reads the settings from the configuration file)</li><li><i>wizard</i> (the default if you don't specify type), datagard asks about every single configuration option</li></ul><p><i>-c &lt;file&gt;</i></p><p>Specifies user defined configuration file name (the default is <i>midgard</i> if you leave out <i>-c</i>)</p><div><i>-a &lt;action&gt;</i></div><div>Action type selection. Possible actions are:</div><ul><li><div><i>install</i>, the default if you don't specify action - installs the database and the Midgard PEAR packages, and then creates a virtual host</div></li><li><div><i>upgrade</i>, upgrade the database and the MidCOM PEAR packages</div></li><li><div><i>vhost</i>, create a new virtual host. This operation requires that the database contains a style template for the vhost. Style templates are imported to the db during the install action</div></li><li><div><i>dbinstall</i>, install a new database and its configuration file. Remember to specify the database name using the <i>-c</i> option if you already have a database called <i>midgard.</i> Keep in mind that this action doesn't import style templates to the db like the install action does<br /></div></li><li><div><i>dbupdate</i>, update the database structure</div></li><li><div><i>pear</i>, install/upgrade Midgard PEAR package(s). Needs Midgard version to be at least the same as the version of the PEAR packages, because the database structure isn't updated beforehand</div></li><li><div><i>sitegroup</i>, create a new domain/sitegroup</div></li></ul></div><div><div><p><i>-p &lt;package name&gt; </i></p></div><div><p>Install a given application or component. </p></div><div><p>When installing a new site with application like OpenPSA: </p></div><pre># datagard -a install -p openpsa</pre></div><div><div><p>When installing/updating new component like midcom_helper_search to an existing Midgard CMS installation:</p></div><pre># datagard -a pear -p midcom_helper_search<br /></pre></div><div><div><p><i>-v &lt;level&gt;</i></p></div><p>Sets verbosity level, numeric option. The default value is 0<br class="GENTICS_ephemera" /></p></div>
